synsets.definition: have the quality of being; (copula, used with an adjective or a predicate noun)
_examples: John is rich
This is not a good answer

synsets.definition: be identical to; be someone or something
_examples: The president of the company is John Smith
This is my house

synsets.definition: occupy a certain position or area; be somewhere
_examples: Where is my umbrella?" "The toolshed is in the back
What is behind this behavior?

synsets.definition: have an existence, be extant
_examples: Is there a God?

synsets.definition: happen, occur, take place; this was during the visit to my parents' house"
_examples: I lost my wallet
There were two hundred people at his funeral
There was a lot of noise in the kitchen

synsets.definition: be identical or equivalent to
_examples: One dollar equals 1,000 rubles these days!

synsets.definition: form or compose
_examples: This money is my only income
The stone wall was the backdrop for the performance
These constitute my entire belonging
The children made up the chorus
This sum represents my entire income for a year
These few men comprise his entire army

synsets.definition: work in a specific place, with a specific subject, or in a specific function
_examples: He is a herpetologist
She is our resident philosopher

synsets.definition: represent, as of a character on stage
_examples: Derek Jacobi was Hamlet

synsets.definition: spend or use time
_examples: I may be an hour

synsets.definition: have life, be alive
_examples: Our great leader is no more
My grandfather lived until the end of war

synsets.definition: to remain unmolested, undisturbed, or uninterrupted -- used only in infinitive form
_examples: let her be

synsets.definition: be priced at
_examples: These shoes cost $100

knowledges.speaker: Rachel

synsets.definition: take something or somebody with oneself somewhere
_examples: Bring me the box from the other room
Take these letters to the boss
This brings me to the main point

synsets.definition: cause to come into a particular state or condition
_examples: Long hard years of on the job training had brought them to their competence
bring water to the boiling point

synsets.definition: cause to happen or to occur as a consequence
_examples: I cannot work a miracle
wreak havoc
bring comments
play a joke
The rain brought relief to the drought-stricken area

synsets.definition: go or come after and bring or take back
_examples: Get me those books over there, please
Could you bring the wine?
The dog fetched the hat

synsets.definition: bring into a different state
_examples: this may land you in jail

synsets.definition: be accompanied by
_examples: Can I bring my cousin to the dinner?

synsets.definition: advance or set forth in court
_examples: bring charges", "institute proceedings

synsets.definition: bestow a quality on
_examples: Her presence lends a certain cachet to the company
The music added a lot to the play
She brings a special atmosphere to our meetings
This adds a light note to the program

synsets.definition: be sold for a certain price
_examples: The painting brought $10,000
The old print fetched a high price at the auction

synsets.definition: attract the attention of
_examples: The noise and the screaming brought the curious

synsets.definition: induce or persuade
_examples: The confession of one of the accused brought the others to admit to the crime as well

knowledges.origin_sent: I didn't mean to bring you down.

synsets.definition: have the quality of being; (copula, used with an adjective or a predicate noun)
_examples: John is rich
This is not a good answer

synsets.definition: be identical to; be someone or something
_examples: The president of the company is John Smith
This is my house

synsets.definition: occupy a certain position or area; be somewhere
_examples: Where is my umbrella?" "The toolshed is in the back
What is behind this behavior?

synsets.definition: have an existence, be extant
_examples: Is there a God?

synsets.definition: happen, occur, take place; this was during the visit to my parents' house"
_examples: I lost my wallet
There were two hundred people at his funeral
There was a lot of noise in the kitchen

synsets.definition: be identical or equivalent to
_examples: One dollar equals 1,000 rubles these days!

synsets.definition: form or compose
_examples: This money is my only income
The stone wall was the backdrop for the performance
These constitute my entire belonging
The children made up the chorus
This sum represents my entire income for a year
These few men comprise his entire army

synsets.definition: work in a specific place, with a specific subject, or in a specific function
_examples: He is a herpetologist
She is our resident philosopher

synsets.definition: represent, as of a character on stage
_examples: Derek Jacobi was Hamlet

synsets.definition: spend or use time
_examples: I may be an hour

synsets.definition: have life, be alive
_examples: Our great leader is no more
My grandfather lived until the end of war

synsets.definition: to remain unmolested, undisturbed, or uninterrupted -- used only in infinitive form
_examples: let her be

synsets.definition: be priced at
_examples: These shoes cost $100

synsets.definition: have or possess, either in a concrete or an abstract sense
_examples: She has $1,000 in the bank
He has got two beautiful daughters
She holds a Master's degree from Harvard

synsets.definition: have as a feature
_examples: This restaurant features the most famous chefs in France

synsets.definition: go through (mental or physical states or experiences)
_examples: get an idea
experience vertigo
get nauseous
receive injuries
have a feeling

synsets.definition: have ownership or possession of
_examples: He owns three houses in Florida
How many cars does she have?

synsets.definition: cause to move; cause to be in a certain position or condition
_examples: He got his squad on the ball
This let me in for a big surprise
He got a girl into trouble

synsets.definition: serve oneself to, or consume regularly
_examples: Have another bowl of chicken soup!
I don't take sugar in my coffee

synsets.definition: have a personal or business relationship with someone
_examples: have a postdoc
have an assistant
have a lover

synsets.definition: organize or be responsible for
_examples: hold a reception
have, throw, or make a party
give a course

synsets.definition: have left
_examples: I have two years left
I don't have any money left
They have two more years before they retire

synsets.definition: be confronted with
_examples: What do we have here?
Now we have a fine mess

synsets.definition: undergo
_examples: The stocks had a fast run-up

synsets.definition: suffer from; be ill with
_examples: She has arthritis

synsets.definition: cause to do; cause to act in a specified manner
_examples: The ads induced me to buy a VCR
My children finally got me to buy a computer
My wife made me buy a new sofa

synsets.definition: receive willingly something given or offered
_examples: The only girl who would have him was the miller's daughter
I won't have this dog in my house!
Please accept my present

synsets.definition: get something; come into possession of
_examples: receive payment
receive a gift
receive letters from the front

synsets.definition: undergo (as of injuries and illnesses)
_examples: She suffered a fracture in the accident
He had an insulin shock after eating three candy bars
She got a bruise on her leg
He got his arm broken in the scuffle

synsets.definition: achieve a point or goal
_examples: Nicklaus had a 70
The Brazilian team got 4 goals
She made 29 points that day

synsets.definition: cause to be born
_examples: My wife had twins yesterday!

synsets.definition: have sex with; archaic use
_examples: He had taken this woman when she was most vulnerable

synsets.definition: perceive by sight or have the power to perceive by sight
_examples: You have to be a good observer to see all the details
Can you see the bird in that tree?
He is blind--he cannot see

synsets.definition: perceive (an idea or situation) mentally
_examples: Now I see!
I just can't see your point
Does she realize how important this decision is?
I don't understand the idea

synsets.definition: perceive or be contemporaneous with
_examples: We found Republicans winning the offices
You'll see a lot of cheating in this school
The 1960's saw the rebellion of the younger generation against established traditions
I want to see results

synsets.definition: imagine; conceive of; see in one's mind
_examples: I can't see him on horseback!
I can see what will happen
I can see a risk in this strategy

synsets.definition: deem to be
_examples: She views this quite differently from me
I consider her to be shallow
I don't see the situation quite as negatively as you do

synsets.definition: get to know or become aware of, usually accidentally
_examples: I learned that she has two grown-up children
I see that you have been promoted

synsets.definition: see or watch
_examples: view a show on television
This program will be seen all over the world
view an exhibition
Catch a show on Broadway
see a movie

synsets.definition: come together
_examples: I'll probably see you at the meeting
How nice to see you again!

synsets.definition: find out, learn, or determine with certainty, usually by making an inquiry or other effort
_examples: I want to see whether she speaks French
See whether it works
find out if he speaks Russian
Check whether the train leaves on time

synsets.definition: be careful or certain to do something; make certain of something
_examples: He verified that the valves were closed
See that the curtains are closed
control the quality of the product

synsets.definition: go to see for professional or business reasons
_examples: You should see a lawyer
We had to see a psychiatrist

synsets.definition: go to see for a social visit
_examples: I went to see my friend Mary the other day

synsets.definition: go to see a place, as for entertainment
_examples: We went to see the Eiffel Tower in the morning

synsets.definition: take charge of or deal with
_examples: Could you see about lunch?
I must attend to this matter
She took care of this business

synsets.definition: receive as a specified guest
_examples: the doctor will see you now
The minister doesn't see anybody before noon

synsets.definition: date regularly; have a steady relationship with
_examples: Did you know that she is seeing an older man?
He is dating his former wife again!

synsets.definition: see and understand, have a good eye
_examples: The artist must first learn to see

synsets.definition: deliberate or decide
_examples: See whether you can come tomorrow
let's see--which movie should we see tonight?

synsets.definition: observe as if with an eye
_examples: The camera saw the burglary and recorded it

synsets.definition: observe, check out, and look over carefully or inspect
_examples: The customs agent examined the baggage
I must see your passport before you can enter the country

synsets.definition: go or live through
_examples: We had many trials to go through
he saw action in Viet Nam

synsets.definition: accompany or escort
_examples: I'll see you to the door

synsets.definition: match or meet
_examples: I saw the bet of one of my fellow players

synsets.definition: make sense of; assign a meaning to
_examples: What message do you see in this letter?
How do you interpret his behavior?

synsets.definition: become pale and sickly
have a great affection or liking for
_examples: I love French food
She loves her boss and works hard for him

synsets.definition: get pleasure from
_examples: I love cooking

synsets.definition: be enamored or in love with
_examples: She loves her husband deeply

synsets.definition: have sexual intercourse with
_examples: This student sleeps with everyone in her dorm
Adam knew Eve
Were you ever intimate with this man?
